title: Koch Fractal
creator: Generated with Claude Code
subject: Mathematics
Geometry

description: An interactive visualization demonstrating the iterative construction of the Koch curve, a classic fractal with self-similar patterns at every scale. Students can adjust the recursion level from 0 to 6 to observe how simple iterative rules create complex fractal patterns.

learningObjectives: Understand how simple iterative rules can create complex patterns
Explore the concept of self-similarity in fractals
Observe how mathematical infinity can be approached through finite iterations
Connect geometric transformations with fractal generation
Calculate fractal dimensions and understand dimensions beyond integers
prerequisites: Basic understanding of line segments and geometric transformations
Familiarity with the concept of iteration
Knowledge of equilateral triangles (helpful but not required)

controls.name: recursionSlider
controls.label: Recursion Level
controls.purpose: Controls the number of iterations in the Koch curve construction. Level 0 shows a straight line, while higher levels show increasingly complex fractal patterns.

variables: baselineY: Vertical position of the fractal baseline
canvasWidth: Responsive width of the drawing canvas
model.algorithm: Recursive Koch curve generation using geometric transformation
model.description: At each recursion level, every line segment is divided into three equal parts, and the middle third is replaced with two sides of an equilateral triangle. This process creates a self-similar fractal pattern.
equations: Length at level n: (4/3)^n × original length
Number of segments at level n: 4^n
assumptions: The fractal is displayed as a 2D projection
Maximum recursion level is limited to 6 for performance
Discrete rendering approximates the theoretical continuous curve
limitations: Does not show the full Koch snowflake (three curves arranged in a triangle)
Does not animate the iterative construction process
Performance may decrease at high recursion levels on slower devices

assessmentOpportunities: Pattern recognition at different recursion levels
Mathematical calculation of length and segments
commonMisconceptions: Believing the curve will eventually smooth out
Thinking infinite length means infinite area
Confusion between recursion level and fractal dimension
